content: I added some missing tests: Reversed Solid Rock, Everybody Crossed The Bridge

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Puzzle has several fun ways for solving. Backstory is engaging :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is really fun and original. I like how you introduced a story background.

I accept it as is, but if I had to make a comment I would try to clarify the rules. I think it would be clearer if you'd highlight the sentence "No character can be on the end of the bridge". Also, precise this is only for the fellowship, but Gandalf and the Balrog can. Finally, maybe you can precise that you can break the bridge even if people stand on it, while they are on the right side

Very good contribution !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tested it in JavaScript: works as expected. Nice problem.

Nice challenge ! 
I don't understand the test "trapped inside Moria", the output is BREAK because no B or G are on the bridge ?

"...on the other side of Gandalf AS the Balrog.." doesn't sound quite right.

Suggestion: 
"...on the other side of Gandalf FROM the Balrog.."
or
"All of the members of the Fellowship (a-z) must be on one side of Gandalf (G). The Balrog (B) must be on the other side."

I think the puzzle is clear enough even if you have no idea what Lord of the RIngs is. Otherwise, it's easy enough to reword the puzzle with a shepherd protecting his sheep from a wolf or something. Any thoughts one way or the other?
seems clear enough to me the way it is worded now ;)
Thanks! It sounds much better now.

The output can only be BREAK if they are both on the bridge. I named it this way because many people would initially assume that B is always to the left of G. This is because the first test case is written this way, and it's how the scene is displayed in the LoTR movie as well. So, keeping this silly assumption means you get a silly conclusion - by breaking the bridge, everyone is "trapped inside Moria." :P

I see what you mean. Those who aren't familiar with the story would assume that "breaking the bridge" would mean the entire bridge, not just a section. I added some clarification to the final section of the statement. Hopefully it's not too clunky!

I'm not sure where "No character can be on the end of the bridge" came from. Maybe someone edited it in? It's directly at odds against the following sentence (my original intent), so I'll remove it unless someone clarifies what they meant.

This sentence is necesarry because if we see something like   `s    b   aG_____ ....` we don't know if a is on the bridge - meaning we can BREAK - or if not and Gandalf is not on the bridge either - in which case we have to WAIT.
Got it. The text should be clear now. Thanks for catching this!

My bad, I forgot to scroll to the right to visualize all the input....
Now everything looks good to me, good job :)
